name: Sorbic Acid
overview: A natural preservative used to inhibit molds, yeasts, and fungi in various foods.
uses: Found in cheese, wine, baked goods, and salad dressings.
precautions: Generally considered safe, but may cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Inhibits the growth of mold, yeast, and some bacteria.
origin: Naturally occurs in some berries; also synthetically produced.

name: Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C)
uses: Prevents oxidation in foods and beverages; also used as a nutritional supplement.
precautions: High doses can cause gastrointestinal distress and kidney stones.
interactions: Essential for collagen synthesis and immune function.
origin: Naturally found in fruits and vegetables; also synthetically produced.
dailyIntake: Not specified, but the recommended daily allowance (RDA) is 65-90 mg.

name: Acesulfame Potassium
overview: Artificial sweetener, 200 times sweeter than sugar.
uses: Sweetens sugar-free drinks, desserts, and baked goods.
precautions: Generally considered safe, but some studies suggest it may affect metabolic processes.
interactions: Not metabolized by the body, excreted unchanged.
origin: Synthetic compound.

name: Aspartame
overview: Artificial sweetener, about 200 times sweeter than sugar.
uses: Sweetens diet sodas, sugar-free gum, and low-calorie desserts.
precautions: Should be avoided by individuals with phenylketonuria (PKU).
interactions: Metabolizes into aspartic acid, phenylalanine, and methanol in the body.
origin: Synthetic compound.

name: Sodium Benzoate
overview: Preservative that inhibits the growth of bacteria, yeast, and molds.
uses: Common in acidic foods like salad dressings, carbonated drinks, and fruit juices.
precautions: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Can form benzene, a carcinogen, when combined with ascorbic acid (vitamin C).
origin: Derived from benzoic acid, which is naturally found in some fruits.

name: Monosodium Glutamate
overview: Flavor enhancer that intensifies savory tastes.
uses: Added to savory snacks, soups, and processed meats.
precautions: Can cause headaches or Chinese Restaurant Syndrome in sensitive individuals.
interactions: May overstimulate nerve cells in high quantities.
origin: Fermented from starch, sugar beets, sugar cane, or molasses.

name: Sodium Nitrite
overview: Preservative and color fixative in cured meats.
uses: Preserves color and prevents bacterial growth in processed meats like bacon and ham.
precautions: Excessive consumption can lead to the formation of nitrosamines, which are carcinogenic.
interactions: Converts to nitrite in the stomach, which can react with amines to form nitrosamines.
origin: Synthetic compound..

name: Sorbitol
overview: Sugar alcohol used as a sweetener and humectant.
uses: Found in sugar-free candies, gums, and diabetic foods.
precautions: Can cause gastrointestinal distress, such as bloating and diarrhea, if consumed in excess.
interactions: Slow absorption can cause a laxative effect.
origin: Naturally occurring in fruits, but commercially produced from glucose.
dailyIntake: Not specified, but typically considered safe up to 20 g/day.

name: Xanthum Gum
uses: Common in salad dressings, sauces, and gluten-free baked goods.
precautions: May cause digestive issues in some people.
interactions: Generally safe, as it is not absorbed into the body.
origin: Produced by fermentation of glucose or sucrose by the bacterium *Xanthomonas campestris.

name: Carrageenan
overview: hickener and stabilizer extracted from red seaweed.
uses: Used in dairy products, plant-based milk, and processed meats.
precautions: May cause gastrointestinal inflammation in some individuals.
interactions: Can cause digestive issues in high doses.
origin: Extracted from red seaweed.

name: Sodium Bicarbonate
uses: Used in baking, effervescent beverages, and cleaning products.
precautions: High intake can lead to metabolic alkalosis.
interactions: Neutralizes acids in the body, altering stomach acidity.
origin: Naturally occurring mineral, also synthetically produced..
dailyIntake: Not specified, but high intake should be avoided.

name: Calcium Propionate
overview: Antifungal agent used as a preservative.
uses: Extends the shelf life of baked goods by inhibiting mold growth.
precautions: Generally recognized as safe, but may cause digestive issues in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Does not accumulate in the body, as it is metabolized and excreted.
origin: Produced by reacting calcium hydroxide with propionic acid.

name: Tartrazine
uses: Used to color beverages, candies, and processed foods.
precautions: Can cause allergic reactions and hyperactivity in sensitive individuals.
interactions: May cause adverse reactions in individuals with aspirin sensitivity.
origin: Synthetic, derived from petroleum.

name: Butylated Hydroxytoluene
uses: Prevents oxidation in oils, fats, and processed foods.
precautions: Controversial due to potential carcinogenic effects in high doses.
interactions: Interferes with free radicals, preventing oxidation.
origin: Synthetic compound.

name: Lecithin
uses: Common in chocolates, margarine, and baked goods.
precautions: Generally considered safe, but may cause mild digestive issues in some people.
interactions: Supports fat digestion, as it is a natural phospholipid.
origin: Derived from soybeans, eggs, or sunflower seeds.

name: Pectin
uses: Used in jams, jellies, and fruit preserves.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can cause digestive discomfort.
interactions: Forms gels in the digestive tract, slowing digestion.
origin: Extracted from citrus peels and apple pomace.

name: Citric Acid
overview: Acidulant that adds a sour taste.
uses: Common in beverages, candies, and canned foods.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can erode tooth enamel.
interactions: Participates in the citric acid cycle in the body, providing energy.
origin: Naturally found in citrus fruits; also produced by fermentation.

name: Glycerol
uses: Found in candies, icings, and soft drinks.
precautions: Generally safe, but can cause headaches and digestive issues in high doses.
interactions: Metabolizes into glucose, providing energy.
origin: Derived from plant oils or animal fats.

name: Sodium Metabisulfite
uses: Preserves the color of dried fruits, wine, and baked goods.
precautions: Can cause allergic reactions, especially in asthmatics.
interactions: Sulfites can cause oxidative stress in sensitive individuals.
origin: Synthetic, derived from sulfur dioxide.

name: Acacia Gum
uses: Used in soft drinks, candies, and confectionery products.
precautions: Generally safe, but may cause mild digestive issues.
interactions: Fermented by gut bacteria, potentially benefiting gut health.
origin: Derived from the sap of the Acacia tree.

name: Potassim Sorbate
overview: Preservative that inhibits mold and yeast growth.
uses: Extends the shelf life of cheese, baked goods, and beverages.
precautions: Generally safe, but may cause skin or eye irritation in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Inhibits microbial growth by interfering with cellular enzymes.
origin: Synthetic compound.

name: Erythritol
overview: Sugar alcohol used as a sweetener.
uses: Found in sugar-free gums, candies, and baked goods.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can cause digestive discomfort.
interactions: Absorbed in the small intestine and excreted unchanged, minimal impact on blood sugar.
origin: Naturally found in some fruits; commercially produced by fermenting glucose.
dailyIntake: Not specified, but typically well-tolerated up to 1 g/kg body weight.

name: Propylene Glycol
uses: Found in frostings, salad dressings, and flavorings.
precautions: Generally safe but can cause allergic reactions or skin irritation in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Metabolized in the liver to lactic acid.
origin: Synthetic compound derived from petroleum.

name: Gelatin
uses: Common in jelly desserts, marshmallows, and gummy candies.
precautions: Generally considered safe but not suitable for vegetarians or vegans.
interactions: Broken down into amino acids in the digestive tract.
origin: Derived from animal collagen, typically from pork or beef.

name: Titanium Dioxide
uses: Used in chewing gum, candies, and powdered sugar products.
precautions: Concerns about potential carcinogenicity in nanoparticle form; usage in food is being re-evaluated in some regions.
interactions: Not absorbed by the body, passes through the digestive system.
origin: Naturally occurring mineral, processed for purity.

name: Guar Gum
overview: Thickener and stabilizer extracted from guar beans.
uses: Found in ice cream, sauces, and gluten-free baked goods.
precautions: Excessive intake can cause digestive issues like gas and bloating.
interactions: Soluble fiber that slows digestion and may help regulate blood sugar levels.
origin: Extracted from the guar plant (Cyamopsis tetragonoloba).

name: Sucralose
overview: Artificial sweetener, about 600 times sweeter than sugar.
uses: Sweetens diet beverages, baked goods, and desserts.
precautions: Generally considered safe, but some studies suggest it may affect gut bacteria.
interactions: Not metabolized by the body, excreted unchanged.
origin: Chemically modified from sucrose.

name: Caramel Color
uses: Used in soft drinks, sauces, and baked goods.
precautions: Some types contain 4-MEI, which is a potential carcinogen.
interactions: Generally safe in small amounts; higher concentrations may pose risks.
origin: Produced by heating carbohydrates like sugar.

name: Polysorbate 80
uses: Found in ice cream, salad dressings, and pharmaceuticals.
precautions: May cause allergic reactions or digestive discomfort in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Helps mix oil and water-based ingredients.
origin: Synthetic compound derived from sorbitol.

name: Calcium Carbonate
uses: Fortifies foods and acts as an anti-caking agent in powdered products.
precautions: Excessive intake can lead to kidney stones and hypercalcemia.
interactions: Neutralizes stomach acid and provides calcium.
origin: Naturally occurring mineral.

name: Tartaric Acid
overview: Acidulant that adds tartness to foods.
uses: Found in wine, soft drinks, and baking powder.
precautions: Generally safe, but high doses can cause gastrointestinal distress.
interactions: Participates in the Krebs cycle, aiding in energy production.
origin: Naturally found in grapes and other fruits.

name: Annatto
overview: Natural food coloring derived from the seeds of the achiote tree.
uses: Colors dairy products like cheese, butter, and margarine.
precautions: Can cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Considered safe and non-toxic.
origin: Derived from the seeds of the achiote tree (*Bixa orellana).

name: Sodium Stearoyl Lactylate
overview: Emulsifier that helps mix fats and water.
uses: Common in baked goods, margarine, and salad dressings.
precautions: Generally safe, but can cause digestive discomfort in large quantities.
interactions: Helps improve texture and volume in baked goods.
origin: Derived from lactic acid and stearic acid.

name: Calcium Disodium EDTA
uses: Prevents discoloration and rancidity in canned foods and dressings.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can lead to mineral depletion.
interactions: Binds to metal ions, preventing oxidation.
origin: Synthetic compound.

name: BHA (Butylated Hydroxyanisole)
uses: Preserves fats and oils in food products.
precautions: Potential carcinogen in high doses; usage is restricted in some countries.
interactions: Prevents oxidative rancidity in fats and oils
origin: Synthetic compound.

name: Sodium Ascorbate
uses: Used to preserve color and freshness in processed meats.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can lead to gastrointestinal discomfort.
interactions: Functions as a source of vitamin C and prevents oxidation.
origin: Derived from ascorbic acid (vitamin C).

name: Lactic Acid
uses: Found in fermented foods, salad dressings, and soft drinks.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can cause tooth enamel erosion.
interactions: Naturally produced in the body during exercise; participates in the energy cycle.
origin: Produced by bacterial fermentation of carbohydrates.

name: Sodium Citrate
uses: Common in beverages, processed cheeses, and pharmaceuticals.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can cause alkalosis.
interactions: Helps maintain pH balance and acts as a preservative.
origin: Derived from citric acid.

name: Potassium Chloride
uses: Used in low-sodium foods, sports drinks, and as a seasoning.
precautions: High intake can cause hyperkalemia, especially in those with kidney issues.
interactions: Maintains potassium levels and balances electrolytes.
origin: Naturally occurring mineral.
dailyIntake: Not specified, but should be moderated.

name: Glucono Delta-Lactone
uses: Found in tofu, cheese, and baked goods.
precautions: Generally safe, but excessive intake can cause metabolic acidosis.
interactions: Slowly hydrolyzes to gluconic acid in water.
origin: Produced by the oxidation of glucose.

name: Paprika Extract
uses: Colors and flavors processed meats, snacks, and sauces.
precautions: Generally safe, but may cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
interactions: Provides carotenoids, which have antioxidant properties.
origin: Extracted from red peppers (Capsicum annuum).

name: Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C)
uses: Prevents oxidation in foods and beverages; also used as a nutritional supplement.
precautions: High doses can cause gastrointestinal distress and kidney stones.
interactions: Essential for collagen synthesis and immune function.
origin: Naturally found in fruits and vegetables; also synthetically produced.
dailyIntake: Not specified, but the recommended daily allowance (RDA) is 65-90 mg.

name: Beet Red
uses: Colors candies, dairy products, and beverages.
precautions: Generally safe, but may cause red urine or stool in high amounts.
interactions: Provides betalains, which have antioxidant properties.
origin: Extracted from beetroot.

name: Silicon Dioxide
uses: Prevents clumping in powdered foods, spices, and supplements.
precautions: Generally considered safe, but inhalation of fine particles can cause respiratory issues.
interactions: Not absorbed by the body, passes through the digestive system.
origin: Naturally occurring mineral.

name: Potassium Nitrate
overview: Preservative and color fixative in cured meats.
uses: Found in cured meats like bacon, ham, and sausages.
precautions: High intake can lead to methemoglobinemia and the formation of carcinogenic nitrosamines.
interactions: Converts to nitrite in the body, which can then form nitrosamines.
origin: Naturally occurring in some vegetables; also synthetically produced.

name: Beta-Carotene
overview: A natural pigment used to color foods and as a source of Vitamin A.
uses: Found in margarine, cheese, and soft drinks.
precautions: Generally safe; excessive consumption may cause carotenemia (yellowing of the skin).
interactions: Converted to Vitamin A in the body, supporting vision and immune function.
origin: Naturally occurs in carrots, sweet potatoes, and other vegetables.

name: Locust Bean Gum
overview: A thickening agent derived from the seeds of the carob tree.
uses: Common in ice cream, cream cheese, and salad dressings.
precautions: Generally considered safe; may cause digestive discomfort if consumed in large amounts.
interactions: Used to improve texture and stability in food products.
origin: Naturally extracted from carob seeds.

name: Fumaric Acid
overview: A food acid used as a preservative and flavoring agent.
uses: Found in fruit juices, gelatin desserts, and baking powders.
precautions: Generally recognized as safe; excessive consumption may cause digestive upset.
interactions: Enhances flavor and preserves freshness in food products.
origin: Synthetically produced or derived from certain fruits.

name: Nisin
overview: A natural preservative produced by fermentation, used to inhibit bacterial growth.
uses: Commonly found in dairy products and canned vegetables.
precautions: Generally considered safe; no significant side effects reported.
interactions: Inhibits the growth of certain bacteria, extending shelf life.
origin: Produced by bacterial fermentation of Lactococcus lactis.

name: Caramel Color
overview: A widely used food coloring that gives a brown color to various foods and drinks.
uses: Common in soft drinks, sauces, and baked goods.
precautions: Generally recognized as safe; some types may contain contaminants.
interactions: Provides color without altering flavor.
origin: Produced by heating sugar with or without acids or alkalis.
